The light beam is directed at the center O of the semicircular brick.
The normal to the semicircular surface at point O is the diameter BC (or a line perpendicular to the tangent at O, which is along the x-axis).
The incident ray makes an angle of 60° with BC.
The angle of incidence, θ1, with the normal to BC (which is vertical in the diagram) is 90° - 60° = 30°.
Applying Snell's Law at O (from air to glass): n_air sin θ1 = n_glass sin θ2.
n_air = 1 (for air), n_glass = √3 (given for red light).
1 * sin 60° = √3 * sin θ2, sin θ2 = 1/2, therefore, θ2 = 30°.
The refracted ray travels from O at an angle of 30° with the vertical.
The brick consists of a semicircle on the left and a right triangle ABC on the right.
The AB side of the right triangle ABC is horizontal.
In triangle ABC, angle A = 30°, angle B = 90°, and angle C = 60°.
The refracted ray leaves O at an angle of 30° with the vertical, making the slope with x-axis 60°.
Equation of ray: y = (tan 60°) x = √3 x.
The line AC passes through C (-R,0) with slope tan 30° = 1/√3.
The ray OD is parallel to the normal to AC, implying i_D = 0°.
The ray continues in a straight line from D towards the screen MN.
The screen MN is a vertical line passing through A, so we need to find the y-coordinate where the ray intersects the vertical line x = x_A.
